task.title: How to Make Frozen Treats for Cerberus
task.shortdesc: Offer Cerberus a calming, mentally stimulating activity that also supports digestion and routine. These frozen treats are helpful during crate time, transitions, or when he’s extra energetic and needs a healthy outlet.

ul.li: Plain Greek yogurt (unsweetened)
Natural peanut butter (xylitol-free)
Plain pumpkin purée
Dry kibble (same food as his regular meals)

prereq.note: Peanut butter is Cerberus's favourite ingredient and helps him stay calm.

ul.li: Mixing bowl and spoon
Ice cube tray, silicone mold, or Kong
Freezer-safe container
Combine yogurt, peanut butter, and pumpkin in a bowl.
Stir in Cerberus’s kibble or treats.

info.note: Aim for a thick but spoonable texture for the base. The kibble or treats give a satisfying crunch.

ul.li: Scoop the mix into your container of choice.

info.note: For a Kong, layer mix–kibble–mix so he stays engaged longer.

step.cmd: Place in the freezer for at least 3 hours or overnight.

postreq.p: Give him a frozen treat during crate time, when guests arrive, or after a long walk.
postreq.note: Cerberus enjoys the treats most after his afternoon walk (around 3 p.m.). Cerberus can get overexcited and gulp the treats, so a little supervision is needed.

ul.li: A bit of low-sodium broth (if picky)
Mashed banana (for sweetness)
Small pieces of frozen watermelon
Keeps him mentally engaged when bored.
Encourages calm chewing (which soothes anxiety)
Slows down eating if he’s overexcited
Adds hydration and digestive support from the pumpkin
Freeze batches ahead and store in a sealed bag or container.
Use within 2 weeks.
If he loses interest, soften the mix with broth or let it thaw for a few minutes.
Always count frozen treats toward his daily food intake.
For crate training, prep one in advance and hand it over as soon as he enters calmly.

postreq.note: Cerberus has tried stuffed bones and lick mats, but he tends to tear apart the rubber lick mats.
